Module jtrim.executor
Package org.jtrim2.executor

Class TaskExecutors

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.executor.TaskExecutors
public final class TaskExecutors extends Object
Contains static helper and factory methods for various useful TaskExecutor and TaskExecutorService implementations.

This class cannot be inherited and instantiated.

Thread safety

Unless otherwise noted, methods of this class are safe to use by multiple threads concurrently.

Synchronization transparency

Unless otherwise noted, methods of this class are synchronization transparent.
See Also:
  • ThreadPoolBuilder

  • Method Details

    • newThreadExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor newThreadExecutor(boolean daemon)
      Returns a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task.
      Parameters:
      daemon - the daemon status of the threads running the tasks of the returned executor
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task. This method never returns null.

    • newThreadExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor newThreadExecutor(boolean daemon, String poolName)
      Returns a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task.
      Parameters:
      daemon - the daemon status of the threads running the tasks of the returned executor
      poolName - the string to be contained in the name of the threads running the tasks of the returned executor. The name of the threads will also contain a unique number to distinguish between threads. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task. This method never returns null.

    • newThreadExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor newThreadExecutor(ThreadFactory threadFactory)
      Returns a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task.

      The threads are created by the provided ThreadFactory. The provided thread factory may not return null object for thread. Doing so will cause a NullPointerException to be thrown to the submitted of the task.

      Parameters:
      threadFactory - the ThreadFactory creating new threads for the submitted tasks. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutor creating a new dedicated thread for each submitted task. This method never returns null.

    • asUnstoppableExecutor

      public static TaskExecutorService asUnstoppableExecutor(TaskExecutorService executor)
      Returns an TaskExecutorService forwarding all of its methods to the given TaskExecutorService but the returned TaskExecutorService cannot be shutted down. Attempting to shutdown the returned ExecutorService results in an unchecked UnsupportedOperationException to be thrown.
      Parameters:
      executor - the executor to which calls to be forwarded by the returned TaskExecutorService. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an TaskExecutorService which forwards all of its calls to the specified executor but cannot be shutted down. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

    • syncNonRecursiveExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor syncNonRecursiveExecutor()
      Returns an executor executing synchronously on the calling thread without calling task recursively. That is, if a task submitted to this executor submits a task to the same executor, the task will not be called immediately but delayed until the top most call returns.

      This executor is useful to prevent too deep calls potentially causing StackOverflowError.

      For example, consider the following code: 

      
 TaskExecutor executor = TaskExecutors.syncNonRecursiveExecutor();
 executor.execute(() -> {
   System.out.print("1");
   executor.execute(() -> System.out.print("3"));
   System.out.print("2");
 });
      The above code will always print "123".

      Note on exceptions: This implementation differs from ExecutorsEx.syncNonRecursiveExecutor the way it handles exceptions happening in a task. That is, an exception happening in any of the tasks will not affect other tasks of the same thread, and their exception can only be accessed through the returned CompletionStage.

      Returns:
      an executor executing synchronously on the calling thread without calling task recursively. This method never returns null.
      See Also:
      • ExecutorsEx.syncNonRecursiveExecutor()

    • inOrderExecutor

      public static MonitorableTaskExecutor inOrderExecutor(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns an executor which forwards task to a given executor and executes tasks without running them concurrently. The tasks will be executed in the order the they were submitted to the execute method of the returned TaskExecutor. Subsequent tasks, attempted to be executed while another one scheduled to this executor is running will be queued and be executed when the running task terminates. Note that even if a tasks schedules a task to this executor, the scheduled task will only be called after the scheduling task terminates. See the following code for clarification: 
      
 void doPrint(TaskExecutor executor) {
   TaskExecutor inOrderExec = TaskExecutors.inOrderExecutor(executor);
   inOrderExec.execute(() -> {
     System.out.print("1");
     inOrderExec.execute(() -> System.out.print("3"));
     System.out.print("2");
   });
 }
      The doPrint method will always print "123", regardless what the passed executor is.

      The returned executor is useful for calling tasks which are not safe to be called concurrently. This executor will effectively serialize the calls as if all the tasks were executed by a single thread even if the underlying executor uses multiple threads to execute tasks.

      Note that this implementation does not expect the tasks to be synchronization transparent but of course, they cannot wait for each other. If a tasks executed by this executor submits a task to this same executor and waits for this newly submitted tasks, it will dead-lock always. This is because no other tasks may run concurrently with the already running tasks and therefore the newly submitted task has no chance to start.

      Note: This method may return the same executor passed in the argument if the specified executor already executes tasks in the order they were submitted. Warning: Instances of this class use an internal queue for tasks yet to be executed and if tasks are submitted to executor faster than it can actually execute it will eventually cause the internal buffer to overflow and throw an OutOfMemoryError. This can occur even if the underlying executor does not execute tasks scheduled to them because tasks will be queued immediately by the execute method before actually executing the task.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor to which tasks will be eventually forwarded to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      executor which forwards task to a given executor and executes tasks without running them concurrently. This method never returns null and may return the same executor passed in the argument if the specified executor executes tasks in the order they were submitted.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null
      See Also:
      • SingleThreadedExecutor
      • inOrderSimpleExecutor(TaskExecutor)

    • inOrderSimpleExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor inOrderSimpleExecutor(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns an executor which forwards task to a given executor and executes tasks without running them concurrently (this method differs from inOrderExecutor(TaskExecutor) only by not necessarily returning a MonitorableTaskExecutor). The tasks will be executed in the order the they were submitted to the execute method of the returned TaskExecutor. Subsequent tasks, attempted to be executed while another one scheduled to this executor is running will be queued and be executed when the running task terminates. Note that even if a tasks schedules a task to this executor, the scheduled task will only be called after the scheduling task terminates. See the following code for clarification: 
      
 void doPrint(TaskExecutor executor) {
   TaskExecutor inOrderExec = TaskExecutors.inOrderSimpleExecutor(executor);
   inOrderExec.execute(() -> {
     System.out.print("1");
     inOrderExec.execute(() -> System.out.print("3"));
     System.out.print("2");
   });
 }
      The doPrint method will always print "123", regardless what the passed executor is.

      The returned executor is useful for calling tasks which are not safe to be called concurrently. This executor will effectively serialize the calls as if all the tasks were executed by a single thread even if the underlying executor uses multiple threads to execute tasks.

      Note that this implementation does not expect the tasks to be synchronization transparent but of course, they cannot wait for each other. If a tasks executed by this executor submits a task to this same executor and waits for this newly submitted tasks, it will dead-lock always. This is because no other tasks may run concurrently with the already running tasks and therefore the newly submitted task has no chance to start.

      Note: This method may return the same executor passed in the argument if the specified executor already executes tasks in submittation order. Warning: Instances of this class use an internal queue for tasks yet to be executed and if tasks are submitted to executor faster than it can actually execute it will eventually cause the internal buffer to overflow and throw an OutOfMemoryError. This can occur even if the underlying executor does not execute tasks scheduled to them because tasks will be queued immediately by the execute method before actually executing the task.

      Parameters:
      executor - the executor to which tasks will be eventually forwarded to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      executor which forwards task to a given executor and executes tasks without running them concurrently. This method never returns null and may return the same executor passed in the argument if the specified executor executes tasks in submittation order.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null
      See Also:
      • SingleThreadedExecutor
      • inOrderExecutor(TaskExecutor)

    • inOrderSyncExecutor

      public static MonitorableTaskExecutor inOrderSyncExecutor()
      Returns an executor which invokes tasks in the order they were scheduled to it. The tasks will execute in one of the execute calls of the same executor but the user has no influence in which one it will actually be called.

      This method is effectively equivalent to calling inOrderExecutor(SyncTaskExecutor.getSimpleExecutor()).

      Returns:
      an executor which invokes tasks in the order they were scheduled to it. This method never returns null.

    • upgradeToStoppable

      public static TaskExecutorService upgradeToStoppable(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns a TaskExecutorService which upgrades the specified TaskExecutor to provide all the features of a TaskExecutorService. Tasks submitted to the returned TaskExecutorService will be forwarded to the execute method of the specified TaskExecutor.

      Shutting down the returned executor will shutdown the returned executor but not the passed TaskExecutor even if it implemented the TaskExecutorService interface.

      Note: If you don't want to shutdown the return TaskExecutorService, you should rather use the upgradeToUnstoppable method.

      Parameters:
      executor - the TaskExecutor to which the returned TaskExecutorService will forward submitted tasks to be executed. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutorService which upgrades the specified TaskExecutor to provide all the features of a TaskExecutorService. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified TaskExecutor is null
      See Also:
      • upgradeToUnstoppable(TaskExecutor)

    • upgradeToUnstoppable

      public static TaskExecutorService upgradeToUnstoppable(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns a TaskExecutorService which upgrades the specified TaskExecutor to provide all the features of a TaskExecutorService except that the returned executer cannot be shut down. Tasks submitted to the returned TaskExecutorService will be forwarded to the execute method of the specified TaskExecutor.

      The returned executor cannot be shut down. Attempting to do so will cause an unchecked UnsupportedOperationException to be thrown.

      Parameters:
      executor - the TaskExecutor to which the returned TaskExecutorService will forward submitted tasks to be executed. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutorService which upgrades the specified TaskExecutor to provide all the features of a TaskExecutorService. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified TaskExecutor is null
      See Also:
      • upgradeToStoppable(TaskExecutor)

    • contextAware

      public static ContextAwareWrapper contextAware(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns an executor which submits tasks to the specified executor and is context aware.

      Note that, tasks passed to the executor specified in the parameters has no effect on the returned executor.

      Parameters:
      executor - the specified executor to which the returned executor will submit tasks to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an executor which submits tasks to the specified executor and is context aware. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

    • contextAwareIfNecessary

      public static ContextAwareTaskExecutor contextAwareIfNecessary(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns an executor which submits tasks to the specified executor and is context aware. If the passed executor is already an instance of ContextAwareTaskExecutor then the passed executor is returned.

      Note that, tasks passed to the executor specified in the parameters may or may not be count as running in the context of the returned executor.

      Parameters:
      executor - the specified executor to which the returned executor will submit tasks to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      an executor which submits tasks to the specified executor and is context aware. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

    • debugExecutorService

      public static TaskExecutorService debugExecutorService(TaskExecutorService executor)
      Returns a TaskExecutorService which forwards tasks to the specified TaskExecutorService but always logs exceptions thrown by tasks sheduled to the returned executor. This is useful when debugging because a TaskExecutorService implementation cannot determine if an exception thrown by a task expected by the client code or not.

      Other than logging exceptions the returned executor delegates all method calls to the appropriate method of the specified executor.

      The exceptions are logged in a SEVERE level logmessage.

      Warning: The returned executor will not log exceptions thrown by cleanup tasks because TaskExecutorService implementations are expected to log or rethrow them.

      Parameters:
      executor - the TaskExecutorService to which method calls are forwarded to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutorService which forwards tasks to the specified TaskExecutorService but always logs exceptions thrown by tasks sheduled to the returned executor. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null

    • debugExecutor

      public static TaskExecutor debugExecutor(TaskExecutor executor)
      Returns a TaskExecutor which forwards tasks to the specified TaskExecutor but always logs exceptions thrown by tasks sheduled to the returned executor. This is useful when debugging because a TaskExecutor implementation cannot determine if an exception thrown by a task expected by the client code or not.

      Other than logging exceptions the returned executor delegates all method calls to the appropriate method of the specified executor.

      The exceptions are logged in a SEVERE level logmessage.

      Parameters:
      executor - the TaskExecutor to which method calls are forwarded to. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      a TaskExecutor which forwards tasks to the specified TaskExecutor but always logs exceptions thrown by tasks scheduled to the returned executor. This method never returns null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - thrown if the specified executor is null
